Q0.reasoning: The case explicitly states whole exome sequencing (WES) is being pursued with UHC coverage.

Q1.reasoning: UHC WES policies specifically address pediatric patients with unexplained developmental delay/intellectual disability; the patient is 6 years old and therefore meets age-based pediatric eligibility.

Q2.reasoning: UHC requires ordering by an appropriate treating specialist or genetics provider; the referral is from neurology and the family has engaged genetics, meeting ordering/provider requirements.

Q3.reasoning: UHC coverage criteria include unexplained developmental delay/intellectual disability as an indication for WES; the patient has nonsyndromic developmental delay and intellectual disability.

Q4.reasoning: UHC typically requires prior appropriate testing (eg, chromosomal microarray and fragile X testing) before WES. Fragile X was done and nondiagnostic, but no CMA is documented, so the required prior test (CMA) has not been completed.

Q5.reasoning: Family history of neurologic disease (maternal uncle with dystonia and ataxia) is present and is relevant to the genetic evaluation and eligibility considerations.

Q6.reasoning: UHC requires pre-test genetic counseling for WES; the family has seen a genetic counselor multiple times and pre-test counseling is complete with plans for post-test follow-up.

Q7.reasoning: CPT 81415 corresponds to whole exome sequencing (proband), which matches the requested WES.

Q8.reasoning: Although age, clinical indication, provider, counseling, and family history meet UHC criteria, a required prior test (chromosomal microarray) is not documented as completed; absence of the required prior testing would render the WES request non-covered at this time.
